name: Davis Treybig
bio: Early stage investor at Innovation Endeavors, focused on computing infrastructure, developer tools, & data. Former PM at Google.

activity.text: It is fun to see so many recent explorations in ways to scale foundation models to larger sequence lengths and deal with the quadratic scaling of self-attention. Some of the recent research work I have found most interesting:

And thanks to the many researchers who have led this work like @simran_s_arora @realDanFu @tri_dao @MichaelPoli6 @exnx @Massastrello @HazyResearch @ai_with_brains @liliyu_lili @simigd @HarshMeh1a @colin__flaherty @MaxMa1987 @violet_zct @XiangKong4 @LukeZettlemoyer @donglixp

replyTo.text:
In an effort to try to understand all these approaches in more depth, I've summarized them in much more detail here: https://t.co/aeRb4PTDsJ

If I am missing any other interesting research in this area, I'd love to see it.

activity.text: Vector databases have very different designs from traditional databases – in particular how the indexes work. Time will tell but I think the only way to do vectors well in a DB is to build the DB to be vector-native bottoms up.
@bernhardsson Do you have any recommendations for the best technical overviews of index structures in vector DBs?

replyTo.text: Vector databases have very different designs from traditional databases – in particular how the indexes work. Time will tell but I think the only way to do vectors well in a DB is to build the DB to be vector-native bottoms up.

activity.text:
🤖 🔒 Large language models in security

@TreybigDavis discusses a number of potential applications:

* SIEM
* SAST
* Email security and phishing
* SOAR
* Data loss prevention and data security
* Remediation
* Vendor security questionnaires and compliance

https://t.co/wY1E9hEiSG
@clintgibler Thanks for sharing Clint!

activity.text: Every Ex-Googler will introduce Bazel at their new gig, every Ex-Facebooker will introduce Facebook Workplace. People who didn’t work in either of those companies know of those tools only because they worked with an Ex-Googler/Facebooker.

@mitsuhiko Seeing more ex-Google teams start to adopt other things that offer similar benefits to Bazel but without the headache - e.g. , https://t.co/qnlOMRzyHY,
https://t.co/2YcLPXBwY3, etc

activity.text: Recently put together a fairly comprehensive “primer” for our team internally on foundation models, covering things across research, productization, cost structure, use cases, architectures, etc. Sharing publicly in case it’s useful to others: https://t.co/6NgZwXVQ80

RT @VladAIonescu: Today we're announcing Earthly CI, our flagship product! 2-20X faster than traditional CI technologies! 🚀

Many thanks to…

Excited to announce our investment in @EarthlyTech and the launch of their CI product! Despite being so central to the lives of every single software engineer, build tools and CI are still mostly terrible - Earthly is trying to change that.

quoted.text:
🚀 We're thrilled to announce the launch of Earthly CI. It's a fast, repeatable CI/CD platform that is super simple to use. Read all about it in the Earthly CI launch blog post.
https://t.co/bB7JbgrZSa

activity.text: Read more about our investment here https://t.co/6B1HGulgcC and check out Earthly if you want fast, repeatable, simple builds.

replyTo.text: Over 1500 build pipelines use Earthly today, including companies like Workday, Roche, Namely, and DeepGenomics. Earthly CI is the first step in solving a huge number of other issues in CICD, including secrets management, artifactories, and flaky tests.

activity.text:
Which dev tools companies are also social networks?

- unique IDs for users
- reputation systems and proof-of-work
- centered around an atomic unit

GitHub (code repos), Hugging Face (ML models), and Postman (API workspaces) come to mind.

@aashaysanghvi_ It’s early but R2C is kind of like this in security. People share scripts to detect common types of security issues or enforce certain types of secure defaults in the semgrep community - some researchers really use this as a primary way to share or highlight issues

replyTo.text:
Which dev tools companies are also social networks?

- unique IDs for users
- reputation systems and proof-of-work
- centered around an atomic unit

GitHub (code repos), Hugging Face (ML models), and Postman (API workspaces) come to mind.

activity.text:
Post-Google cheat sheet:
MoMA: @glean
Buganizer: @linear
Workday: Workday 😱
Blaze: @turborepo (you can do bazel but do yourself the favor)
Rasta: @statsigio 
Gmail: Slack
Google Docs: @NotionHQ 
Gaia: a world of painful disjoint identity models

@cramforce @glean @linear @turborepo @statsigio @NotionHQ https://t.co/qnlOMRzyHY is interesting in the Bazel/Blaze category. Turbo is awesome for JavaScript, and there are numerous good build tools for other languages, but Earthly is a layer on top of these that offers similar speed/reproducibility benefits as Bazel.

activity.text:
0/ Descriptions of finding product market fit, and category creation often miss the hard part of getting to $10m in ARR ...

... which is the crazy effort required to tug, pull and hammer the shit out of the product *and* the market to make them hold together 👇

@martin_casado Martin do you have any favorite resources you’d recommend (blog, podcast, book) that talk in detail about examples of startups that faced a category creation market like this where they had to do a ton of education, services, etc in order to eventually succeed?

replyTo.text:
11/ Finally, market annealing is fucking hard. You can hammer away at a market for years and have almost nothing to show for it. 

But even in incredibly unrelenting markets, it’s possible to build large companies. You just have to be able to endure the pain long enough.  /fin

activity.text:
https://t.co/KrrMl6qOmn

After having spent time with countless applied large language model startups over the past few years, I can't help but feel that UX is chronically undervalued in this space, despite being arguably the hardest thing to get right (not modeling/data/tech).

If you're a builder or researcher in this space, I'd love any thoughts/feedback you have on the article. I would especially love to talk to a designer who has thought a lot about the UX of LLMs. I am also very interested in any other HCI-related research in this space!

replyTo.text: The article references a number emerging startups and projects doing interesting things from a UX perspective, like @Replit @github @getanyword @copy_ai @tabnine @askviable @enterpret_ai @DebuildHQ @GoogleAI, as well some interesting research in the space that touches on UX

activity.text: A machine learning model I would love to have is something that given a code change predicts the probability of failure for each unit test. Then (a) runs those tests first (b) skips tests with probability below some very low threshold
@bernhardsson This is essentially what https://t.co/E5fYJ2dusP does

replyTo.text: A machine learning model I would love to have is something that given a code change predicts the probability of failure for each unit test. Then (a) runs those tests first (b) skips tests with probability below some very low threshold

activity.text:
I've found that the most fruitful seed / early-stage investment sourcing paths are usually non-linear, not straightforward, and often meandering. 

You're not handed a list of companies to go call.

@aashaysanghvi_ I feel like this sort of “curiosity driven” sourcing is one of the best paths I’ve seen. Hear or read about something new and interesting, and just follow the rabbit hole all the way down into that ecosystem.

replyTo.text: - watched a YT presentation of market I was interested in --> saw an OSS project mentioned --> emailed founder who was still at his previous job --> left job --> many months before seed transpired

activity.text:
Excited to announce our investment in @continual_ai! The rise of the modern data stack has laid the foundation for a new massive company to be built in the MLOps space, and we think @tristanzajonc and Tyler Kohn are the right team to go after it. 

https://t.co/q2ZaWVXJd9
If you're a company on the modern data stack trying to move more into predictive analytics and ML, we recommend you try it out :)

replyTo.text: The blend of simplicity and power is truly elegant, and reminiscent of what dbt has done to the data engineering world. Indeed, if you're a dbt user, Continual's core workflow will immediately resonate with you - it is delightful.
